Supported Ops¶

Binary¶

quanta_SL.ops.binary.bit_roll(x: nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[None, nptyping.types._number.Int], d: int) → nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[None, nptyping.types._number.Int]¶

Roll x to left / right by d bits

Parameters

  • x – integer array

  • d – roll

Returns

quanta_SL.ops.binary.dim_str(dims: int = 1)¶

Return string corresponding to array dimensions :param array: :return:

quanta_SL.ops.binary.left_bit_roll(x: nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[None, nptyping.types._number.Int], d: int, num_bits: Optional[int] = None) → nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[None, nptyping.types._number.Int]¶

Roll x to left by d bits

In n<<d, last d bits are 0. To put first d bits of n at last, do bitwise or of n<<d with n >>(INT_BITS - d)

Parameters

  • x – integer array

  • d – roll

  • num_bits – total bits. If None, set as log2(x.max())

Returns

quanta_SL.ops.binary.packbits(x: nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[None, nptyping.types._number.Int], mode: str = 'left-msb') → nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray¶

Pack an binary array into its integer representation. Axis assumed to be last Unlike numpy, returns an integer, not uint8. Similar to MATLAB’s de2bi

Parameters

  • x – Binary array.

  • mode – Left MSB (default) or Right MSB.

Returns

quanta_SL.ops.binary.packbits_strided(bit_array: numpy.ndarray, xp: module = <module 'numpy' from '/Users/varun/miniconda3/envs/torch39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/numpy/__init__.py'>)¶

Pack binary values in strides of 8 (a byte) to uint8. We do this to save memory. Last axis assumed to be bits.

Numpy/ Cupy allocate 1 byte for a boolean, which is 8x higher than needed (1 bit).

Parameters

  • bit_array – height x width x num_bits x samples

  • xp – Numpy or Cupy

Returns

quanta_SL.ops.binary.right_bit_roll(x: nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[None, nptyping.types._number.Int], d: int, num_bits: Optional[int] = None) → nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[None, nptyping.types._number.Int]¶

Roll x to right by d bits

In n>>d, first d bits are 0. To put last d bits of at first, do bitwise or of n>>d with n <<(INT_BITS - d)

Parameters

  • x – integer array

  • d – roll

  • num_bits – total bits. If None, set as log2(x.max())

Returns

quanta_SL.ops.binary.unpackbits(x: nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[None, nptyping.types._number.Int], num_bits: int = 0, mode: str = 'left-msb') → nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray¶

Unpack an integer array into its binary representation. Similar to MATLAB’s de2bi

Parameters

  • x – Integer array. For large integers use object dtype, python allows storing arbitrarily large ints. Numpy ctypes cannot do so. For more info, see here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18296035/how-to-extract-the-bits-of-larger-numeric-numpy-data-types

  • num_bits – Number of bits in the final representation If less than ceil(log2(x.max())), we will drop the MSB bits accordingly. Else, we pad sufficiently (to the MSB).

  • mode – Left MSB (default) or Right MSB.

Returns

quanta_SL.ops.binary.unpackbits_strided(byte_array: numpy.ndarray, num_bits: int = 0, xp: module = <module 'numpy' from '/Users/varun/miniconda3/envs/torch39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/numpy/__init__.py'>)¶

Unpack uint8 array generated by packbits_strided Last axis assumed to be bytes

Parameters

  • byte_array – array of bytes

  • num_bits – Since bits are padded to nearest multiple of 8 while packing, zero padding can be removed

  • xp – Numpy or Cupy

Returns

Coding Theory Ops¶

Coding theory related

Alias for field number 2

framewise_minSW¶

Alias for field number 1

minSW¶

Alias for field number 0

quanta_SL.ops.coding.hamming_distance_8bit(xp: module = <module 'numpy' from '/Users/varun/miniconda3/envs/torch39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/numpy/__init__.py'>)¶

Hamming distance of each 8-bit uint (in binary representation).

>>> hamming_distance_8bit(5) # 3
>>> hamming_distance_8bit(8) # 1
>>> hamming_distance_8bit(0) # 0
Returns

array with Look Up Table

quanta_SL.ops.coding.stripe_width_stats(code_LUT: numpy.ndarray)¶

Stripe width statistics (run length) of a coding strategy :param code_LUT: Look up table describing the code. The code frames are

c_0[0], c_1[0], …, c_N[0] . . . . . . c_0[n-1], c_1[n-1], …, c_N[n-1]

Where N is the number of messages, n is the code dimension. Typically, N= 2^k C : F^k o F^n

We account for circular shift while calculating stripe width

Returns

minimum stripe width across all frames frame-wise minimum stripe width frame-wise average stripe width

Math¶

General math funcs

All kept pure

quanta_SL.ops.math_func.comb(n, r)¶

Binomial coefficient, nCr, aka the “choose” function n! / (r! * (n - r)!)

Faster than math.comb XD!

quanta_SL.ops.math_func.fast_factorial(n)¶

Fast LUT based factorial :param n: :return:

quanta_SL.ops.math_func.list_error_correcting_capacity(bch_tuple: quanta_SL.encode.metaclass.BCH) → int¶

Based on BCH LECC limit. See Wu et al. 2008, https://arxiv.org/pdf/cs/0703105.pdf.

Parameters

bch_tuple – Describes BCH code as [n, k, t] n: Code length k: Message length t: Worst case correctable errors

Returns

List Error Correcting Capacity

Parameters

  • array – float array

  • axis – Which axis to operate on. Default None (across all).

Returns

Parameters

  • noisy_bits – Corrupted bits per code

Corrupted x

quanta_SL.ops.noise.photon_arrival(num_frames: int, phi: nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[typing.Any, typing.Any, nptyping.types._number.Float], t_exp: Union[float, nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[typing.Any, typing.Any, nptyping.types._number.Float]], size: Tuple[int]) → nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[typing.Any, typing.Any, nptyping.types._number.Int]¶

Simulate SPAD photon arrival. Operating in Quanta SPAD mode. Each frames thresholded if it receives atleast 1 photon

Parameters

  • num_frames – Oversampling rate

  • phi – Incident photon flux (in seconds^-1)

  • t_exp – Exposure time (in seconds)

  • size – Number of samples to draw, usually, (h x w x vec_length)

Returns

Number of frames active

quanta_SL.ops.noise.shot_noise_corrupt_gpu(code: nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[None, nptyping.types._number.Int], phi_P: nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[typing.Any, typing.Any, nptyping.types._number.Float], phi_A: nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[typing.Any, typing.Any, nptyping.types._number.Float], t_exp: Union[float, nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[typing.Any, typing.Any, nptyping.types._number.Float]], num_frames: int = 1, tau: Union[float, nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[typing.Any, typing.Any, nptyping.types._number.Float]] = 0.5, use_complementary: bool = False) → nptyping.types._ndarray.NDArray[None, nptyping.types._number.Int]¶

Corrupt a code word with shot noise

Parameters

  • code – Code word in F_2^n

  • phi_P – Photon flux in “on” state

  • phi_A – Photon flux in “off” state

  • t_exp – SPAD exposure time

  • num_frames – Number of frames to repetitively capture at the SPAD end

  • tau – Threshold (normalized by num_frames). 1 if #photons > num_frames * tau 0 otherwise

  • use_complementary – Use complementary strategy to compare. Involves projecting a code and its complement. Compare the #photons to figure out. Effective only when num_frames > 1.

Returns

Quanta-SL
